newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: Singapore beefs up fight against software piracy.
newsitem.headline: Singapore beefs up fight against software piracy.

text.p: Singapore intensified its fight against software piracy on Wednesday with the launch of an auditing programme targetted at businesses.
A leading software piracy watchdog promised corporations and small businesses that agreeing to having their software examined would ensure a year's immunity from raids and possible civil suits.

The private watchdog, the Business Software Alliance (BSA) told a software conference that its new Corporate Recognition Programme, endorsed by the government, aimed to curb rising rates of software piracy in Singapore.

"(It) will 'protect' companies against raids, civil suits and possible embarrassment that result from tip-offs or sabotage attempts by disgruntled current or ex-employees," BSA vice president Stuart Ong told Reuters on the sidelines of the conference.
He said auditors would conduct checks on companies and certify them free of illegal software. If fake software were found later on their premises, they would not be prosecuted.
According to BSA figures, Singapore's software piracy rate rose in 1996 by six percentage points to 59 percent.

Businesses must pay for genuine software and need to understand the implications of a civil suit, in which they can face heavy financial damages as well as a loss of reputation, brought for using fakes, Ong said.
Ong said five firms had already agreed to take part in the programme and that he hoped to get another 100 to 200 members in a year.
Singapore's software piracy rate has increased by more than 10 percent since 1995, according to the latest BSA figures.
"With the advent of CD-ROMs, the pirates have found an ideal mechanism to distribute 20, 30 sometimes up to 50 programmes," Ong said. There was good demand for it, he added.
A compilation CD-ROM, the most common method of data storage for high-end computers and multimedia equipment, cost only a few dollars to produce and sold for about Singapore $15 (US$10.3), Ong said.
But he said raids on software retailers at shopping complexes around Singapore had only affected retailers and not users.
Ong said piracy syndicates were getting very sophisticated, operating across the music, video and computer software industries.
So far, an engineering and one design and publishing firm had been sued, and a third case was being settled, Ong said.
Singapore courts have adopted stiff penalities -- jail terms of up to 36 months and Singapore $180,000 in fines for those found selling illegal software.
The engineering company found guilty of using fake software was ordered to pay S$42,000 in damages and costs.
